Fig. 1 Reactions involved in direct synthesis of H2O2: (a) H2O2 formation, (b) direct H2O formation, (c) H2O2 decomposition, and (d) H2O2 hydrogenation. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Illustration of catalyst preparation process; (a) impregnation of UiO-66 with Pd NPs, (b) incorporation of hydrophobic linker on Zr nodes of Pd/UiO-66, and (c) subsequent pyrolysis of thus-formed catalyst. Fig 2 Fig. 3 PXRD patterns of UiO-66, UiO-66-C18, Pd/UiO-66-C18, and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 DRIFTS analysis of UiO-66, UiO-66-C18, Pd/UiO-66-C18, and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 catalysts. Fig 4 Fig. 5 SEM-EDX maps and elemental compositions of (a, c) Pd/UiO-66-C18 and (b, d) Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673. Fig 5 Fig. 6 TEM images and Pd NP size distributions of (a) Pd/UiO-66, (b) Pd/UiO-66-C18, (c) Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673, and (d) Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py873. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (A) XPS survey scan and (B) P 2p, (C) Zr 3p, Pd 3d, and (D) C 1s XPS spectra of (a) Pd/UiO-66, (b) Pd/UiO-66-C18, and (c) Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Wettabilities of (a) UiO-66, (b) UiO-66-C18, (c) Pd/UiO-66-C18, (d) Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673, and (e) Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py873 and (f) digital photographs of two-phase systems composed of aqueous and toluene phases containing Pd/UiO-66 and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Effect of OPA concentration on catalytic activity for direct synthesis of H2O2. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Effect of incorporation of hydrophobic linker and subsequent pyrolysis on reaction performance of Pd/UiO-66 catalyst for direct synthesis of H2O2. Fig 10 Fig. 11 (a) H2O2 decomposition and (b) H2O2 hydrogenation performance of Pd/UiO-66 catalyst after incorporation of hydrophobic linker and/or pyrolysis. Table 1 Catalyst Surface area(m2/g) Pore volume(cm3/g) Mean pore diameter (nm) UiO-66 1275.4 0.56 1.75 Pd/UiO-66 1169.9 0.50 1.73 Pd/UiO-66-C18 1019.7 0.44 1.71 Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 170.6 2.03 47.73 Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py873 11.8 0.05 18.62 Strategy for improving H2O2 selectivity during direct H2O2 synthesis: Using palladium catalyst supported on UiO-66 functionalized with hydrophobic linker Xuan Tin Tran Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Validation Writing – original draft Viet Le Nam Vo Methodology Data curation Validation Writing – original draft Young-Min Chung Conceptualization Methodology Resources Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Kunsan National University, 558 Daehak-ro, Kunsan, Jeollabuk-Do 54150, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering Kunsan National University 558 Daehak-ro Kunsan Jeollabuk-Do 54150 Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering, Kunsan National University, 558 Daehak-ro, Kunsan, Jeollabuk-Do 54150, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding Author Ensuring high H2O2 selectivity during its direct synthesis without using any caustic additives remains an elusive goal. Herein we propose a new and effective strategy for improving the H2O2 selectivity of a Pd/UiO-66 catalyst by incorporating a C18 hydrophobic linker on the Zr metal nodes of the catalyst and subsequently subjecting it to pyrolysis. The functionalization of the external surface of Pd/UiO-66 with the linker turns it hydrophobic without changing its textural properties. While the H2 conversion decreased because of the increase in mass-transfer resistance after the incorporation of the long-alkyl-chain linker, the hydrophobic external surface of Pd/UiO-66-C18 efficiently prevented H2O2 from reapproaching the active Pd sites, thereby improving the H2O2 selectivity considerably from 38% to 56%. Furthermore, the H2O2 selectivity was as high as 70% after the subsequent pyrolysis of Pd/UiO-66-C18; this was, however, at the expense of an additional H2 conversion decrease, owing to the partial decomposition of the UiO-66 structure. These results clearly show that controlling the hydrophobicity of the catalyst support is essential for ensuring high H2O2 selectivity, and that the incorporation of a hydrophobic linker and the subsequent pyrolysis of the resulting catalyst is a promising strategy for achieving this goal. Graphical Abstract : Image, graphical abstract Keywords UiO-66 hydrophobic linker direct synthesis hydrogen peroxide H2O2 selectivity Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is used extensively as a green and efficient oxidant in various industrial fields and applications such as the pulp and textile industries, disinfection, water treatment, and fine chemical synthesis [1–3]. Generally, H2O2 is produced by the well-known Riedl-Pfleiderer (anthraquinone autoxidation or AO) technique, which involves energy-intensive processes that generate unwanted waste [4–6]. While commercial H2O2 production continues to rely on the AO process, as concerns about the environmental impact of this process increase, significant efforts are being made to develop alternative technologies for use in H2O2-dependent industries [3,7]. In this context, the environmentally benign nature of the direct synthesis of H2O2 from H2 and O2 (DSHP) makes it a promising option. In principle, H2O2 can be produced by the simple reaction without generating any harmful by-products [4,8,9]. In practice, however, the promise of the DSHP reaction has not been realized owing to the inherent issues related to its thermodynamics and safety [10,11]. The existing solutions for overcoming these problems such as using a corrosive acid/halide additive and regulating the H2 concentration to levels lower than the explosion limit (< 5%) significantly undermine the attractiveness of the DSHP reaction [3,10,12]. Therefore, for an alternative technology to satisfy the industrial and environmental criteria, its H2O2 selectivity during the DSHP reaction should be as high as 70%. In addition, it should not require the use of any caustic promoters and be performed under intrinsically safe reaction conditions [6,8]. From a mechanistic viewpoint, however, improving the H2O2 selectivity in the absence of a side-reaction-suppressing additive is challenging because not only the H2O2 formation reaction (i.e. the DSHP reaction) but also the water formation reactions, i.e. the direct H2O formation reaction), H2O2 decomposition reaction, and H2O2 hydrogenation reaction, are catalyzed by the same active metal, viz. Pd, as described in Fig. 1 [3,13]. Moreover, all these competing reactions are thermodynamically more favorable than the DSHP reaction, making it even more difficult to improve the H2O2 selectivity [8,12]. The last few decades have seen the development of diverse strategies related to catalyst design to meet the economic and environmental requirements for the DSHP reaction, including the sophisticated control of the active metal and supporting materials used as well as their different combinations [5–9,11,14,15]. For example, there have been many studies focused on the retardation of the O–O scission reaction on the active sites by controlling the geometric and electronic features of the metal nanoparticles (NPs) used by fine-tuning their size, shape, and oxidation state, introducing a ligand, or forming a bimetal. This is because the O–O scission reaction is primarily responsible for the formation of H2O [4,8–10,15–19]. Moreover, a wide range of organic and inorganic supports, including carbons [20–26], metal oxides [27–30], zeolites [31,32], mesoporous materials [33,34], metal-organic frameworks [35], and porous polymers [36], have also been explored. Using milder additives and noble reactor designs is another strategy being evaluated [8,11,15]. However, despite these extensive studies, achieving high H2O2 selectivity during the DSHP reaction without using any corrosive additives remains difficult, the remarkable developments described above notwithstanding. We attempted to solve this challenging problem by preventing the H2O2 from reapproaching the active catalyst sites. In this context, we assumed that the active sites would need to exist in a hydrophobic environment such that they would become inaccessible to the hydrophilic H2O2. This, in turn, would increase the H2O2 selectivity by suppressing or retarding both the H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation reactions (reactions (c) and (d) in Fig. 1). It should be noted that the introduction of an active metal, such as Pd, on a ready-made hydrophobic support would not work because the Pd NPs exposed on the external catalyst surface would still be readily accessible to the H2O2. This would limit the effectiveness of the proposed hydrophobization strategy. Therefore, finding an efficient method that would allow the Pd NPs to exist in a hydrophobic environment was essential for this strategy to succeed. Herein we propose a new and simple approach for realizing this goal. Specifically, a hydrophobic long-alkyl-chain linker, viz. octadecylphosphonic acid (C18H39O3P, OPA), was incorporated on the Zr metal nodes of the catalyst Pd/UiO-66. OPA, which is an amphiphilic organic molecule consisting of a hydrophilic head and hydrophobic tail, is readily chemisorbed on various metal and oxide surfaces via strong metal-oxygen-phosphorus bonds [37–40]. UiO-66 was selected as a supporting material due to its high stability during a catalyst preparation including metal-impregnation, post-functionalization, and thermal treatment as well as during a reaction in a methanol/water mixed solution. This hydrophobization strategy was ideal because the grafting of the hydrophobic linker on the metal nodes resulted in a hydrophobic environment for the “already-supported” Pd NPs. In addition, the resulting hydrophobic-linker-attached Pd-UiO-66 catalyst was subsequently subjected to pyrolysis to further enhance its hydrophobicity. As discussed later, the changes in the physicochemical properties of the catalyst by the incorporation of the hydrophobic linker and its subsequent pyrolysis exerted significant impact on the catalytic performance, especially, on the H2O2 selectivity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals used Octadecylphosphonic acid (C18H39O3P, 97%, OPA), terephthalic acid (C8H6O4, 98%, H2BDC), and zirconium (IV) chloride (ZrCl4, ≥ 99.9%), were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Tetraamminepalladium (II) nitrate solution (Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2, 5 wt% as Pd) was obtained from Strem Chemicals. Ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.5%), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 34.5 wt%), methanol (CH3OH, 99.8%), N, N-dimethylformamide (C3H7NO, DMF, 99.5%), and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 35∼37%), were purchased from Samchun Chemicals, South Korea. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of UiO-66 In a typical solvothermal process, 1.17 g of ZrCl4 (5 mmol), 0.84 g of terephthalic acid (5 mmol), and 0.94 mL of HCl (10 mmol) were mixed in 100 mL of DMF under ambient conditions. The mixed solution was then subjected to ultrasonication for 10 min to dissolve the precursors completely. The resulting homogeneous solution was placed in two 100-mL Duran bottles and heated at 393 K for 24 h. The white sample was filtered by using a glass filter funnel and washed with DMF/methanol sequentially after being cooled to ambient temperature. After then, the powder was dried at 423 K for 12 h in vacuo. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Pd/UiO-66 Pd/UiO-66 was prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation using a cationic precursor, Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2. Briefly, 0.5 mL of the cationic precursor solution was slowly added onto the UiO-66 support (1.0 g) under thorough mixing (Pd intake amount: 1 wt%). The resulting powder was stored at 298 K for 12 h and dried at 393 K for 4 h. The obtained powder was then calcined under air at 523 K (ramping rate = 5 K/min) for 3 h. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Pd/UiO-66-C18 Typically, Pd/UiO-66 (0.05 g) was immersed in 50 mL of an ethanol solution containing 1 mM OPA at 298 K. The slurry was agitated for 10 min every 2 h during the first 8 h and then left to stand for 16 h. The resulting powder was separated by centrifugation and rinsed with ethanol thoroughly to remove the OPA residue. And then, the brown powder was dried overnight at room temperature and then heated at 393 K for 24 h in vacuo. Pd/UiO-66-C18 samples with other concentrations (0.5 and 5 mM) were also prepared for comparison. 2.2.4 Synthesis of Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py and Pd/UiO-66-Py The pyrolysis of Pd/UiO-66-C18 was performed in an inert atmosphere using a tube furnace. The temperature was raised slowly from ambient temperature to 673 or 873 K (ramping rate = 5 K/min) and kept at the target level for 3 h. The heating was performed in an atmosphere of nitrogen gas (100 mL/min). After being cooled to ambient temperature, the remaining dark brown (673 K) or black (873 K) powder was collected and stored in a cabinet desiccator till further use. The catalyst samples obtained after pyrolysis at 673 and 873 K are denoted as Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py873, respectively. For comparison, Pd/UiO-66-Py673 and Pd/UiO-66-Py873 were prepared by the pyrolysis of Pd/UiO-66 at 673 and 873 K, respectively. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of catalysts were analyzed by using a high-resolution X-ray diffractometer (Malvern Panalytical Empyrean, England) with Cu/Kα (λ = 1.54 Å) irradiation source. Diffuse-reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analysis was carried out using an FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet iS50, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with a diffuse reflectance IR compartment (DIFFUSIRTM, Pike Technologies, USA). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the samples were recorded at 77 K on a BELSORP-Max system (BEL, Japan) to examine the changes in their textural properties. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on an SDT 650 system (TA Instruments, USA) to investigate the thermal stability of the catalysts. The catalyst powder being tested was placed in an aluminum pan and heated from 298 to 1073 K (ramping rate = 5 K/min) in flowing nitrogen. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was carried out on an ICP-OES analyzer (iCAP7400DUO, Thermal Fisher Scientific, USA) to determine the Pd content of each catalyst. The morphology of the catalyst was examined using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) and the chemical composition of the samples was confirmed using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) attached to the high-resolution FE-SEM (SU8820, Hitachi, Japan). The particle size distribution of Pd NPs on UiO-66 was investigated using transmission electron microscopy (Titan G2 ChemiSTEMTM, FEI Company, USA) operated at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a VG MultiLab 2000 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) instrument to examine the electronic properties and surface elemental compositions of the catalysts. The wettability of each catalyst was evaluated by dropping 10 µL of water on its surface using a micropipette. 2.4 Direct synthesis of H2O2 The DSHP reaction was performed at 275 K without any corrosive/halide promoters using a high-pressure autoclave reactor (Picoclave (100 mL), Büchiglassuster, Switzerland). The catalyst (20 mg) and a methanol/water mixed solution (50 mL, v/v = 4/1) were loaded into the reactor. The reactor lid was sealed and the reactor was pressurized to 5 bar using mixed gases, including 5 vol% H2/N2 (10 mL/min) and 20 vol% O2/N2 (30 mL/min), and released again to sweep any gaseous impurities. The residual gases were removed by purging three times, followed by a reaction pressure increase to 30 bar by the mixed gases, which was maintained using a back pressure regulator (Tescom, USA). After then, the reaction mixture was vigorous stirred (1200 rpm) for 1 h using a magnetically driven gas-entrainment impeller. Mixed N2 (91.2 vol%), H2 (3.8 vol%), and O2 (5.0 vol%) gases were continuously supplied to the reactor during the reaction. After the reaction was completed, the used catalyst was filtered from the reaction solution. The H2O2 concentration of the reaction solution was determined by titration using the acidic cerium (IV) sulfate solution in the presence of a ferroin indicator. To examine the H2 concentration change, the reaction off-gas was analyzed using a gas chromatography (GC) system (Agilent 6890, USA) equipped with a Carboxen-1010 PLOT capillary column and a thermal conductivity (TCD) detector. The H2O2 selectivity and H2 conversion were calculated from the H2O2 and H2 concentrations according to the following equations determined by the titration and GC analysis, respectively. The H2O2 productivity is defined as the amount of H2O2 produced per hour divided by the Pd content (mmol H2O2/g Pd.h). H 2 C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = M o l e s o f H 2 r e a c t e d M o l e s o f H 2 s u p p l i e d × 100 H 2 O 2 S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = M o l e s o f H 2 O 2 p r o d u c e d M o l e s o f H 2 r e a c t e d × 100 2.5 H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation tests The H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation tests were performed at 275 K under atmospheric pressure. Briefly, the catalyst powder (20 mg) and a 1 wt% H2O2 methanol/water solution (50 g) were loaded to a three-necked round-bottom flask and stirred continuously at 300 rpm for 1 h using a magnetic stirrer. N2 or H2 gas (10 mL/min) was continuously supplied to the reactor during the reaction. The liquid sample was periodically extracted for titration to determine the changes in the H2O2 concentration. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of Pd/UiO-66 functionalized with hydrophobic linker As described in Fig. 2 , the Pd/UiO-66 catalyst functionalized with the hydrophobic linker was prepared by sequentially introducing Pd NPs onto the UiO-66 surface, then grafting OPA on the Zr nodes of the formed Pd-impregnated UiO-66, and finally pyrolyzing the catalyst. The catalyst samples obtained from these three steps are denoted as Pd/UiO-66, Pd/UiO-66-C18, and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 or 873, respectively. The crystallinities and phase purities of UiO-66, Pd/UiO-66, Pd/UiO-66-C18, and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 were determined using PXRD analysis. As presented in Fig. 3 , the XRD peaks of UiO-66 are highly consistent with its standard pattern reported elsewhere [41,42]. The characteristic XRD pattern of UiO-66 remained unchanged in the cases of Pd/UiO-66 and Pd/UiO-66-C18, implying that the crystal structure of UiO-66 remained intact after the Pd NP impregnation and OPA incorporation processes. After pyrolysis at 673 K, however, the XRD peaks of UiO-66 almost disappeared, indicating the partial thermal decomposition of UiO-66. The absence of the XRD peak at 2θ = 40o, which was attributable to Pd(111), even after pyrolysis is probably indicative of the uniform dispersion of the Pd NPs and/or the low Pd content of the catalyst [43–45]. The changes in the DRIFTS spectrum with the incorporation of OPA and the subsequent pyrolysis step are presented in Fig. 4 . Regardless of whether OPA was grafted or not, diffuse reflectance signals originating from the Zr metal nodes and the H2BDC linker of UiO-66 were observed. For example, the strong peak appearing at 3671 cm–1 could be assigned to the free µ3-OH groups belonging to the Zr6 clusters of UiO-66 [42,46], while the peak at approximately 3442 cm–1 was attributable to the intercrystalline and/or physisorbed water condensed within the cavities [41]. The two peaks at 1600 and 1450 cm–1 were related to the in- and out-of-phase stretching modes of the –COOH groups, respectively [41,47], whereas the peak at 1517 cm–1 was related to the C=C vibrations of the benzene ring [47]. Finally, the peaks at approximately 751, 695, 575, and 501 cm–1 corresponded to the bending of the –OH and –CH groups [41,47]. For UiO-66-C18 and Pd/UiO-66-C18, new peaks appeared at approximately 2925 and 2856 cm–1 after the grafting of OPA (Fig. 4 (b)); these were related to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching of the -CH2 groups of OPA, respectively [39,48]. Moreover, these peaks matched the characteristic peaks of OPA (Fig. S1), thus confirming that OPA was successfully incorporated on the UiO-66 surface. The slight difference between the peaks of UiO-66-C18 and Pd/UiO-66-C18 suggested that the Pd NPs, impregnated on the UiO-66 surface, had little effect on the OPA grafting process. After pyrolysis, significant changes were observed in the DRIFTS spectrum. The high-intensity peaks located at 3671 and 3442 cm–1 became weaker, suggesting the partial removal of the µ3-bridging hydroxyl groups on the Zr6 clusters and the intercrystalline water within the cavities of UiO-66. The decrease in the peak at approximately 1600 cm–1 may be related to the partial elimination of the –COOH groups of the H2BDC ligand in the UiO-66 framework. In addition, the decrease in the intensities of the peaks located at 575 and 501 cm–1 suggested the partial loss of the -OH and -CH groups of the H2BDC ligand. The gradual removal of the various functional groups sustaining the UiO-66 structure resulted in its significant collapse during the thermal treatment, as also confirmed by the PXRD analysis. However, in the case of Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673, the presence of peaks related to OPA at approximately 2925 and 2856 cm–1 indicated that the OPA structure remained intact after pyrolysis. TGA was also carried out to examine the thermal decomposition behavior of the Pd/UiO-66-C18 catalyst. The first weight loss, which happened at a temperature lower than 373 K, was related to the removal of the physisorbed water from the sample as shown in Fig. S2 [49,50]. The second weight loss, which occurred between 373 and 573 K, was ascribable to the removal of the intercrystalline water and DMF from the cavities of UiO-66 [47,49]. The third major weight loss, which occurred between 573 and 873 K, was related to the significant decomposition of both H2BDC and OPA in this temperature range [50,51]. The complete decomposition of Pd/UiO-66-C18 was observed after 773 K. Thus, the TGA results suggested that the OPA is relatively more stable than UiO-66 during pyrolysis at 673 K, in keeping with the DRIFTS results. It was reported that OPA-functionalized oxide supports remain intact till 673 K when heated in an inert atmosphere [52,53]. The changes in the textural properties of UiO-66 during the catalyst preparation process were investigated by performing gas sorption analysis. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and textural properties of the various catalysts are given in Fig. S3 and Table 1 , respectively. UiO-66, Pd/UiO-66, and Pd/UiO-66-C18 showed type-I sorption isotherms, suggesting a typical microporous structure [44,54,55], whereas Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py873 displayed type-V sorption isotherms, which indicated a typical meso-/macroporous structure [56,57]. Although the surface area of UiO-66 was decreased slightly by the sequential impregnation of the Pd NPs and the incorporation of OPA, its pore volume and diameter remained unchanged, implying that the microporous nature of UiO-66 was unaffected by the catalyst preparation process. After pyrolysis at 673 and 873 K, however, the surface area of UiO-66 was significantly reduced to 170.6 and 11.8 m2/g, respectively, suggesting the partial and complete collapse of the UiO-66 structure, respectively, as also confirmed by the TGA results. The SEM-EDX maps of Pd/UiO-66-C18 and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 presented in Fig. 5 show that elements C, O, Zr, Pd, and P were present on the surface of UiO-66. The presence of P further confirmed that OPA was incorporated successfully on the UiO-66 surface [48,58] and that some of it remained even after pyrolysis at 673 K. That the C/O ratio of Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 was higher compared with that of Pd/UiO-66-C18 can be attributted to the partial removal of the hydroxyl and carboxyl groups on the Zr6 clusters and H2BDC ligand during pyrolysis, as also suggested by the DRIFTS results. TEM analysis was carried out to observe the variations in the Pd NP size and distribution during the catalyst preparation process. As presented in Fig. 6 , the Pd NPs were well dispersed on the UiO-66 surface, and there was little difference in the Pd NP sizes and distributions of Pd/UiO-66 and Pd/UiO-66-C18, indicating that the Pd NP size was not affected by the grafting of OPA. Moreover, the Pd NP size remained unchanged even after pyrolysis at 673 K, implying that the degree of sintering that occurred at this temperature was low. Since it is difficult to prevent the unwanted sintering of Pd NPs at that temperature [59,60], this result is interesting. It is likely that the grafted long-alkyl-chain linker effectively retarded or suppressed the sintering of the Pd NPs during pyrolysis at 673 K. However, the enlarged Pd NP size of the Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py873 indicates that significant sintering of the Pd NPs was inevitable during pyrolysis at 873 K. XPS analysis was carried out to examine the electronic properties and elemental compositions of the catalysts. As can be seen in Fig. 7 (A), the XPS survey spectrum of Pd/UiO-66 contained Zr 3d, C 1s, Zr 3p, Pd 3d, and O 1s peaks [43,54,55]. The presence of the P 2p peak in the spectra of Pd/UiO-66-C18 and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 further confirmed the successful incorporation of OPA on the Zr nodes. It also confirmed that the grafted OPA was retained after pyrolysis at 673 K (Fig. 7(B)). The deconvoluted Zr 3p XPS spectra of all the catalysts contained two peaks at 333.2 and 346.9 eV (Fig. 7(C)), which corresponded to Zr 3p3/2 and Zr 3p1/2, respectively [44,55]. In addition, the two peaks at ca. 337 and 342 eV in the deconvoluted Pd XPS spectra could be attributed to the Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 states of Pd2+, respectively [43]. It should be noted that it was difficult to observe the variations in the electronic nature of Pd, i.e. determine the Pd0/Pd2+ ratio, during the catalyst preparation process because the binding energies of Zr 3p and Pd 3d are similar, and the intensity of the Pd peak was relatively smaller than that of the Zr peak [55]. However, the fact that the binding energy of the Pd 3d3/2 peak was the same for all the catalysts implies that there was little change in the electronic property of Pd during the OPA grafting and subsequent pyrolysis processes. The three deconvoluted peaks present in the C 1s spectrum of Pd/UiO-66 were related to the carbon skeleton C–C (284.6 eV), ether groups C–O–C (285.2 eV), and carboxyl groups O–C=O (288.6 eV), respectively (Fig. 7(D)) [61,62]. In the case of Pd/UiO-66-C18, the higher intensity of the peak at approximately 285 eV can be ascribed to the carbon bound to oxygen (C–O) and the carbon bound to phosphorous (C–P) because of the incorporation of OPA [58]. However, the peak intensity was significantly reduced after pyrolysis owing to the removal of oxygen groups from UiO-66. To examine the enhanced hydrophobicity of Pd/UiO-66 after the incorporation of OPA, wettability tests were performed. As shown in Fig. 8 , the complete wetting observed in the case of UiO-66 indicated that it was highly hydrophilic [63,64]. On the other hand, the significantly lower wettabilities of UiO-66-C18 and Pd/UiO-66-C18 suggested that the UiO-66 surface turned superhydrophobic because of a decrease in its energy and/or tension after the incorporation of OPA [56,65,66]. The low wettabilities of Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py873 also suggested that the hydrophobicity was maintained even after the decomposition of both UiO-66 and OPA at 873 K as well as that of UiO-66 at 673 K. Figure 8(f) provides further evidence of changes in the surface characteristics of UiO-66 after the grafting of OPA and pyrolysis. While Pd/UiO-66 was preferentially dispersed in the aqueous phase, Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 was completely transformed into an organic phase. The wettability test confirmed that the proposed hydrophobization strategy involving the incorporation of a hydrophobic linker on the Zr nodes and subsequent pyrolysis is efficient for turning hydrophilic UiO-66 superhydrophobic. 3.2 Effect of hydrophobic linker on catalytic activity for DSHP reaction To examine the effectiveness of the hydrophobization strategy, a series of Pd/UiO-66-C18 samples was prepared using different OPA concentrations, and their catalytic activities for the DSHP reaction were examined. Figure 9 shows clearly that the OPA concentration exerted huge impact on the overall reaction performance, including the H2 conversion, H2O2 selectivity, and H2O2 productivity. Indeed, the H2O2 selectivity increased with the OPA concentration. An improvement of approximately 50% in the H2O2 selectivity (from 38% to 56%) was achieved with the use of 1 mM of OPA, clearly indicating that the incorporation of OPA on the UiO-66 structure played an essential role in the enhancement of the H2O2 selectivity. In other words, the OPA-induced hydrophobic environment around the Pd NPs was effective in improving the H2O2 selectivity. However, the linear decrease in the H2 conversion with the increase in the OPA concentration suggested that the access of the H2 and O2 molecules to the active Pd sites was impeded by the hydrophobic linker, with the mass-transfer resistance increasing with the increase in the amount of the hydrophobic linker used [67]. When 5 mM of OPA was used for hydrophobization, the H2O2 selectivity increased slightly, whereas the H2 conversion continued to decrease linearly, implying that increasing the OPA concentration does not result in a continuous increase in the H2O2 selectivity. 3.3 Effect of additional pyrolysis step on catalytic activity for DSHP reaction After confirming the potential and limitations of the OPA incorporation strategy in terms of its effect on the H2O2 selectivity, an additional pyrolysis step was performed to further increase the hydrophobicity of the Pd/UiO-66-C18 catalyst by removing the hydrophilic oxygen-containing functional groups of UiO-66. For this purpose, Pd/UiO-66-C18 was pyrolyzed at different temperatures, i.e. 673 (soft pyrolysis) and 873 K (hard pyrolysis). As presented in Fig. 10 , the pyrolysis temperature had a determining effect on the degree to which the pyrolysis process impacted the catalytic performance. For Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673, which was prepared by soft pyrolysis, the H2O2 selectivity was as high as 70%, which is 1.84 and 1.25 times higher than those of Pd/UiO-66 and Pd/UiO-66-C18, respectively. As listed in Table S1, the catalytic performance of Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 was one of the highest values among the state-of-the-art catalysts tested under an intrinsically safe reaction condition in the absence of additives. It is interesting that the H2O2 selectivity was high in the case of Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673, which exhibited poor textural properties because of the decomposition of the UiO-66 structure during pyrolysis. This result further confirms the importance of using a hydrophobic catalyst for improving the H2O2 selectivity [67,68]. It also reconfirms that the proposed hydrophobization strategy, which combines the incorporation of a hydrophobic linker and a subsequent pyrolysis step, is highly effective for enhancing the H2O2 selectivity. In contrast to the positive effect of the pyrolysis step on H2O2 selectivity, the H2 conversion decreased after pyrolysis at 673 K, probably owing to a further decrease in the accessibility of the active sites because of the collapse of the well-ordered UiO-66 structure. For Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py873, there was no improvement in the H2O2 selectivity, indicating that the OPA grafting–pyrolysis method has limitations and that there exist optimal conditions for maximizing the H2O2 selectivity. While it was assumed that the surface of the Pd/UiO-66-C18 catalyst becomes more hydrophobic after pyrolysis at 873 K, the deterioration of its textural properties (Table 1) and the severe sintering of the Pd NPs (Fig. 6) were clearly responsible for the observed decrease in the catalytic activity. Under the high-temperature conditions (873 K), the Pd NPs migrated toward the outer surface and formed aggregates. This reduced the effectiveness of the hydrophobization strategy, as the exposed Pd NP aggregates accelerated the undesirable H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation reactions [24,60,69]. In contrast, the H2 conversion did not decrease significantly with increasing pyrolysis temperature. It seems that the exposed Pd NPs partially helped overcome the mass transfer problem, while the accessibility of the active sites by the reactants worsened after hard pyrolysis. It is noted that a simple pyrolysis of Pd/UiO-66 can be an efficient hydrophobization strategy. However, the lower H2 conversion and H2O2 selectivity of Pd/UiO-66-Py673 compared with those of Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 suggest that the pyrolysis of Pd/UiO-66 after hydrophobic linker grafting is superior in maximizing H2O2 selectivity. Moreover, the lowest H2O2 selectivity obtained in the presence of Pd/UiO-66-Py873 catalyst showed the essential role of hydrophobic linker in improving H2O2 selectivity. 3.4 Effect of hydrophobic linker and pyrolysis on H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation reactions With respect to the DSHP reaction, H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation are primarily responsible for the low H2O2 selectivity and determine the overall reaction performance. Therefore, the use of corrosive acids and halides during the DSHP reaction has been considered inevitable for suppressing the unfavorable subsequent reactions of the generated H2O2 (Fig. 1) [8–10]. In this context, to examine whether the proposed hydrophobization strategy is efficient in suppressing these undesirable competitive side-reactions, H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation were carried out using Pd/UiO-66, Pd/UiO-66-C18, and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 catalysts. Both the H2O2 decomposition and H2O2 hydrogenation rates were reduced noticeably after the incorporation of the hydrophobic linker and reduced further after the subsequent pyrolysis step as shown in Fig. 11 . In particular, there was a remarkable decrease in the H2O2 hydrogenation rate after the hydrophobization process. It should be noted that preventing H2O2 hydrogenation is of prime importance for ensuring high H2O2 selectivity because the reaction is faster than the H2O2 decomposition reaction and thus primarily responsible for low H2O2 selectivity during the DSHP reaction [10,27]. In this context, the lowest H2O2 selectivity of Pd/UiO-66-Py873 catalyst can be understood by the faster H2O2 decomposition and H2O2 hydrogenation rates. Moreover, the higher H2 conversion of Pd/UiO-66-Py873 catalyst is mainly ascribed to the faster H2O2 hydrogenation rate. Based on the results discussed above, the notable improvement observed in the H2O2 selectivity in the cases of Pd/UiO-66-C18 and Pd/UiO-66-C18-Py673 can be explained in terms of the efficient suppression of the H2O2 decomposition reaction, and particularly, the H2O2 hydrogenation reaction in the presence of these catalysts. The incorporation of the hydrophobic linker on the Zr nodes of Pd/UiO-66 ensures that the Pd NPs are in a hydrophobic environment as described in Fig. 12 . While not only the adsorption of H2 and O2, but also the desorption of the generated H2O2 to and from the hydrophobic-linker-surrounded Pd NPs may be retarded slightly, such hydrophobic microenvironment efficiently prevents the H2O2 from reapproaching the active Pd sites. The pyrolysis of Pd/UiO-66-C18 further enhances the H2O2 selectivity by improving the hydrophobicity. Thus, these results confirm that the proposed hydrophobization strategy consisting of the incorporation of a hydrophobic linker and subsequent pyrolysis is a simple and efficient one for ensuring high H2O2 selectivity under intrinsically safe reaction conditions without using a corrosive promoter. 4 Conclusion Herein we proposed and evaluated a new and simple strategy for ensuring high H2O2 selectivity during the direct synthesis of H2O2. The underlying idea is to ensure that the Pd catalyst is in a hydrophobic environment, making it inaccessible to the hydrophilic H2O2. To realize this, a C18 hydrophobic linker, viz. octadecylphosphonic acid, was incorporated onto the Zr nodes of UiO-66, which had been impregnated previously with Pd NPs. An additional pyrolysis step was performed to further enhance the hydrophobicity of the catalyst by removing the oxygen-containing groups of UiO-66. Characterization confirmed that while the UiO-66 structure was maintained during the Pd impregnation and hydrophobic linker incorporation steps, it collapsed partially/completely during pyrolysis at 673/873 K. Activity tests revealed that the hydrophobic environment induced by the grafting of the hydrophobic linker and the sequential pyrolysis step was highly effective in enhancing the H2O2 selectivity, which increased to 70%. The observed improvement in the H2O2 selectivity can be attributed to the effectiveness of the hydrophobic environment in suppressing the H2O2 decomposition reaction, and particularly, the H2O2 hydrogenation reaction. Thus, the proposed hydrophobization strategy is highly effective for ensuring high H2O2 selectivity during the direct synthesis of H2O2 under safe reaction conditions without using any corrosive additives. coredata.dc:description: Ensuring high H2O2 selectivity during its direct synthesis without using any caustic additives remains an elusive goal. Herein we propose a new and effective strategy for improving the H2O2 selectivity of a Pd/UiO-66 catalyst by incorporating a C18 hydrophobic linker on the Zr metal nodes of the catalyst and subsequently subjecting it to pyrolysis. The functionalization of the external surface of Pd/UiO-66 with the linker turns it hydrophobic without changing its textural properties. While the H2 conversion decreased because of the increase in mass-transfer resistance after the incorporation of the long-alkyl-chain linker, the hydrophobic external surface of Pd/UiO-66-C18 efficiently prevented H2O2 from reapproaching the active Pd sites, thereby improving the H2O2 selectivity considerably from 38% to 56%. Furthermore, the H2O2 selectivity was as high as 70% after the subsequent pyrolysis of Pd/UiO-66-C18; this was, however, at the expense of an additional H2 conversion decrease, owing to the partial decomposition of the UiO-66 structure. These results clearly show that controlling the hydrophobicity of the catalyst support is essential for ensuring high H2O2 selectivity, and that the incorporation of a hydrophobic linker and the subsequent pyrolysis of the resulting catalyst is a promising strategy for achieving this goal.
coredata.dc:title: Strategy for improving H2O2 selectivity during direct H2O2 synthesis: Using palladium catalyst supported on UiO-66 functionalized with hydrophobic linker
